verses.text: You shall not see your brother’s ox or his sheep straying and ignore them; you must surely return them to your brother.
verses.comment: In the original Hebrew, 'brother' refers to a fellow Israelite. The word 'ignore' is a literal translation.

verses.text: And if your brother does not live near you, or if you do not know him, then you must bring it to your own house, and it shall stay with you until your brother seeks it; then you shall return it to him.
verses.comment: Phrase 'bring it to your own house' means to keep the animal safely, not to claim ownership.

verses.text: And you shall do the same with his donkey, with his garment, and with any lost thing of your brother’s, which he loses and you find; you may not ignore it.
verses.comment: Expanded to include all types of lost property.

verses.text: You shall not see your brother’s donkey or his ox fallen down on the road and ignore them; you shall surely help him lift them up.
verses.comment: Retains the force of the Hebrew phrase 'surely help.'

verses.text: A woman shall not wear a man’s clothing, nor shall a man put on a woman’s garment, for whoever does these things is detestable to the LORD your God.
verses.comment: Literal rendering. No idioms or reinterpretations added.

verses.text: If you come across a bird’s nest along the way, in any tree or on the ground, with young ones or eggs, and the mother sitting on the young or on the eggs, you shall not take the mother with the young.
verses.comment: Translation keeps the structure of the Hebrew.

verses.text: You must surely let the mother go, but you may take the young for yourself, so that it may go well with you and you may live long.
verses.comment: 'So that it may go well with you' is a common Deuteronomic blessing formula.

verses.text: When you build a new house, you shall make a parapet for your roof, so that you do not bring blood upon your house if anyone falls from it.
verses.comment: 'Parapet' means a protective barrier. Context is flat roofs in ancient Israel.

verses.text: You shall not sow your vineyard with two kinds of seed, or all the yield of the seed you have sown and the increase of the vineyard will be defiled.
verses.comment: 'Defiled' renders Hebrew word meaning 'set apart as forbidden.'

verses.text: You shall not plow with an ox and a donkey together.
verses.comment: Literal rendering of Hebrew idiom about mixing animals for plowing.

verses.text: You shall not wear cloth of wool and linen mixed together.
verses.comment: Follows closely the Hebrew language for 'mixed together.'

verses.text: You shall make tassels on the four corners of the cloak with which you cover yourself.
verses.comment: 'Tassels' renders the Hebrew 'tzitzit.'

verses.text: If a man takes a wife and goes in to her and then hates her,
verses.comment: 'Hates her' is a Hebrew idiom meaning 'turns against her' or 'rejects her.'

verses.text: and accuses her of shameful things and gives her a bad reputation and says, ‘I took this woman, and when I came near her, I did not find evidence of virginity in her,’
verses.comment: Phrase 'evidence of virginity' is a literal translation of the Hebrew.

verses.text: then the father and mother of the young woman shall take and bring out evidence of her virginity to the elders of the city at the gate.
verses.comment: 'Elders of the city at the gate' refers to the place where judgment was made.

verses.text: And the young woman’s father shall say to the elders, ‘I gave my daughter to this man as a wife, and he hates her;
verses.comment: 'Hates her' repeated for parallelism with v. 13.

verses.text: and behold, he has accused her of shameful things, saying, “I did not find evidence of your daughter’s virginity.” But here is the evidence of my daughter’s virginity.’ And they shall spread the cloth before the elders of the city.
verses.comment: The 'cloth' is a literal reference to a physical sign presented as evidence.

verses.text: Then the elders of that city shall take the man and punish him.
verses.comment: Literal. 'Punish' is general, as Hebrew is not specific here.

verses.text: And they shall fine him one hundred shekels of silver and give them to the young woman’s father, because he has brought a bad name upon a virgin of Israel. And she shall be his wife; he may not divorce her all his days.
verses.comment: 'May not divorce her' is a clear rendering of the Hebrew, which forbids separation.

verses.text: But if the thing is true, and evidence of virginity was not found in the young woman,
verses.comment: Literal; follows Hebrew sequence.

verses.text: then they shall bring out the young woman to the door of her father’s house, and the men of her city shall stone her to death with stones, because she has done a disgraceful thing in Israel by playing the harlot in her father’s house. So you shall purge the evil from your midst.
verses.comment: 'Playing the harlot' is a literal translation of the Hebrew idiom for sexual immorality.

verses.text: If a man is found lying with a woman married to a husband, then both of them shall die, the man who lay with the woman and the woman. So you shall purge the evil from Israel.
verses.comment: Literal rendering; 'lying with' is Hebrew idiom for sexual relation.

verses.text: If there is a virgin pledged to be married to a husband, and a man finds her in the city and lies with her,
verses.comment: 'Pledged to be married' or 'betrothed.'

verses.text: then you shall bring them both out to the gate of that city and stone them to death with stones, the young woman because she did not cry out in the city, and the man because he has violated his neighbor’s wife. So you shall purge the evil from among you.
verses.comment: Emphasis is on both participants and the need for justice.

verses.text: But if in the open country the man finds the woman who is pledged to be married and forces her, and lies with her, then only the man who lay with her shall die.
verses.comment: 'Forces her' renders Hebrew for rape.

verses.text: But to the young woman you shall do nothing; there is in the young woman no sin deserving death. For just as when a man rises against his neighbor and kills him, so is this case.
verses.comment: Draws a direct parallel to murder; preserves the legal structure.

verses.text: For he found her in the open country, and though the betrothed young woman cried out, there was no one to save her.
verses.comment: Literally, 'no one to save her.'

verses.text: If a man finds a young woman, a virgin who is not pledged to be married, and he seizes her and lies with her, and they are found,
verses.comment: 'Seizes her' represents a debated Hebrew word; context indicates forced sexual contact.

verses.text: then the man who lay with her shall give to the young woman’s father fifty shekels of silver, and she shall be his wife because he has violated her. He may not divorce her all his days.
verses.comment: 'Violated her' is the literal Hebrew. Divorce prohibition repeated from earlier in the chapter.

verses.text: A man shall not take his father’s wife, and he shall not uncover his father’s skirt.
verses.comment: 'Uncover his father’s skirt' is a Hebrew euphemism for incest.
